Try it out yourself!

user_tags: Urban Explorer;Like a Local;Thrill Seeker;Nightlife Seeker
review_title: Great Argentine food at great prices
review: This place is the real deal: great genuine Argentine food, friendly service, nice ambience and very reasonable (non tourist) prices. I am an Argentine living in the U.S., so I know! We were in Buenos Aires for a week and despite the countless restaurants in the Palermo area, we just had to go back to this restaurant twice.  Try the classic "provoleta" as a starter. It is an Argentine staple, as is the chicken milanesa as a main course. For those who like something sweet and new, try their mashed sweet potatoes. They are not the same root vegetable as eaten in the U.S. It's sweeter and more fragrant. The dulce de leche pancakes for dessert are a great way to end a fabulous meal. I hope you enjoy it as much as we did!

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;History Buff
review: I really enjoyed great steaks here. But it’s necessary to come here with more than 6 people, because this restaurant provides us with so much meat. So there aren’t enough people, you couldn’t enjoy all of good steaks.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: I was there in summer time that was great place with good air conditioner that you can eat and feel cool not freezing. We have stake with sweet potatoes and chips that was great that we both enjoy our meal . Only one thing I can say is they do not do 1/2 Asado that I love it’s only a porción that is Hugh for one. The service is good and also they do NOT charge cubierto that is typically in Arg that is not the tip it’s ( extras as bread , butter or anything you not order and put on table . But also could be to used their chairs
great salad and the chorizo was nice as well. friendly waitress. reasonable prices. nice seating on sidewalk so you can people watch

My wife and I passed this restaurant for days before we decided to give it a try. It was worth it. We had a great meal and the servers were very helpful with describing the menu and offering opinions on our choices. Cheryl had the pulled pork and I had the skirt steak. We have learned that in Argentina the quality of the beef is very good and the vast majority is free range grass fed. BUT, almost all chefs have a tendency to over cook the beef compared to our North American standards so adjust your preference and clarify the redness / pinkness you want your steaks.

review_title: Good quality food, not too fancy but cooked with taste
review: We went there with a small party after work at around 8 PM, which by local standards is early. We had several dishes without starter (which did not lead to strange looks as it does in some other places) as we headed for steak and alike. All enjoyed their food and I was happy to see my steak turning up red (as asked!). One serious drawback: the French fries were clearly not prepared as should. That's a shame.

user_tags: Like a Local;Nightlife Seeker;Beach Goer;Luxury Traveler
review: And i say this because it was our first dinner in Argentina and would repeat, had a good provoleta, chorizo and a corte vacio that were very good, place a bit tight and loud for my likes but not bad at all!

I was in La Dorita last Sunday, more or less one year after my previous visit. It was again a great experience. Not only the meat is great but also the portions are huge for my Brazilian standards. Our party of 6 ordered one salad, two chorizos, french fries, one entraña and one colita de cuadril (which in Brazil se call picanha). We ordered the colita because they did not have asado de tira which was our first option. All was accompanied by a penguin of malbec (they have 3 barrels of wine over the counter and fill half or one litter ceramic penguins to bring to the table). The meat and the chorizos were cooked to perfection. That is what a parrilla is about. We did not have problems with the service as mentioned in some comments. It was just correct. The bill including one shared ice cream with dulce de leche and service was AR$700, not bad at all. Go to La Dorita for great parrilladas...

review_title: Ok, but there are better places
review: I was here recently. It was recommended by someone I know in Buenos Aires. Personally, I thought the service was a little slow, and the food was only average. I do not think that I would return.  While not having a lot of bad things to say, I also do not have a lot of good things to say either.  I got to the restaurant about 9:30 on a Saturday evening. It was not easy to get a seat, and was seated immediately. About 10 PM, the restaurant appeared to be full.  The portion served was more than I could eat. However, I have a lot better meat at other places in town. The chocolate mousse that I had for dessert was quite good.  While the desserts may be good at Parrilla La Dorita, there are many other places to go in Buenos Aires to get a good steak.  Overall, I would not go back the Parrilla La Dorita.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Vegetarian;Foodie;Like a Local
review: I don't eat meat so what the hell was I doing coming here? Bottom line - it was the only place still open at 11.30pm and I was starving! Apparently the beef is great but I ordered salmon which was just OK - surrounded by a myriad of roasted veggies; again it was just OK The wine was utterly foul - no selection offered by the glass...by at $25 ARG it was not cheap. I dined at a table outside; lots of shady characters hanging about so it wasn't a relaxing experience at all. If you must eat here then get a table inside at least. Bar scene seemed busy and fun however.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Like a Local;History Buff;60+ Traveler
review: Large portions, meat tough. Salad large enough to share with two people. Grilled provolone cheese was excellent. Best part was the penquin of cinzano! Service good. Portion size large, under order, you can always order more but if you order too much it is overwhelming.

review_title: good stakes but arrived too cold
review: The place is nothing fancy, more of a neighborhood joint, but it has its charm about it, seams more authentic than touristy. I have to say the quality of the meats was very good. Each of us had different steak and all of them were cooked properly and were tasty, but also all of them arrived barely warm. The service was pleasant, but regular. Prices more of a standard. Good place for families with children as you can sit outside also.

I've been to this Parrilla twice and was very pleased both times. The atmosphere is average but the food is good. I had "Pollo a la Parilla" with grilled vegetables and it was delicious. The service was also great at this restaurant and the food came out pretty quickly. The last time I went to La Dorita I went with a friend and our bill came to about 180.00 pesos - certainly not cheap but neither was it expensive for Buenos Aires standards. I definitely recommend!

user_tags: Urban Explorer;Like a Local;Thrill Seeker;Nature Lover
review: We visited this restaurant for both lunch and dinner several times. Lunch time they have Menu Executivo for 50 pesos (main course + side + drink) or 60 pesos (starter + main course + side + dessert+ drink). We tried both pastas, milanesas, bifes and salads - and all was delicious. In the evening we had empanadas, chorizo (sausage), bife de lomo, and bife de chorizo with chimichurri. Excellent meat and nice athmosphere and service.

review_title: EXCELLENT STEAKHOUSE WITH VERY GOOD SERVICE
review: We dined here on our first night whilst staying in Palermo Soho. Although we could have walked to this restuaran, a local taxi was less than £2.  We chose an Empanada to start but only one between two knowing the size of steaks to follow. The waiter spoke now english but brought to our table the size of 3 different steaks. We chose the Tenderloin ( like Filet Steak ) As mentioned in previous reviews, one steak shared between two is ample! A reasonable priced Pinot Noir was selected and advised by the waiter for £12.  A choice of mashed potato or thick chips as well as an extra of vegetables.  Total cost of meal for two inc wine £41.  We were so pleased, we visited again the following evening as we were unable to obtain a table at Don Julio although on reserve list for 3 weeks!  A thorough recommendation BUT be careful on the portions!

review_title: Best steaks in Buenos Aires, trust me
review: Came for lunch today, wanted to eat a good steak, this place did the trick! From the moment we walked in we knew we had the right spot. Great restaurant, menu, service, and vibe for Argentinean grill!  We had the Arugula Salad with Parmesan, and it was excellent. They dress it for you too.  For lunch, we ordered the "Tablita de Carne" which is a 2pp platter of grilled meat. Was excellent too. But the best was the Paillard de Lomo - probably in the top 5 steaks I've had in the world. Trust me on this one. I also tasted the Medallon de Lomo (the thick cut) and it was insanely delicious too. We had a side of papas fritas too, which were huge.  In all, this is a very nice restaurant, not quite "fine dining" but in that genre. You will want to come back!

Our server at first seemed to be offended when we all ordered pasta. He said "No Meat???" and reluctantly took our order. We later got to know him better and he provided us with excellent service. Thanks Christian. The food was also very good. I ordered a standard spaghetti Bolognesa which was one of the best that I have ever tasted. The others ordered Lasagna and other pasta dishes, and along with the house salad ( HUGE!!) the food was all very good and generous.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Nature Lover;Luxury Traveler
review: We were lucky to get a table for two without a reservation on our first night in BA. However, we arrived at 7pm and when we left, every table was filled. And for good reason! The rib eye steak we shared was exceptional. Perfectly grilled and so flavorful. We also shared a salad and grilled vegetables. Ample portions - in fact we left half the salad and veggies. But we finished every bite of the steak. With a bottle of wine and tip, our bill came to $45. Try getting that in the USA!

We went here on the recommendation of Hila our Tango teacher and we were. Ot disappointed. The beef de lomo was the best I have tasted. Be prepared for a large steak! Alfonso the waiter was very helpful. Surprisingly we also shared a chocolate fondant pudding with ice cream.... So indulgent. The prices were very reasonable. Highly recommended.

review_title: Incredible steak - would absolutely eat here again
review: I think this may be one of the best steaks I’ve ever had.  Firstly, really nice location and restaurant is modern and clean.  Menu is fantastic and reasonably priced. Waiter made some brilliant recommendations. Steak was absolutely sensational. I can not fault it.  Wine was also on top form - the Malbec recommendation I had was brilliant.  I would highly recommend this place.

As part of a fishing party to Rio Grande we had a stop either end in Buenos Aires and each time dined at this wonderful restaurant. The variety of quality steaks was great, the Malbec was superb and the waiting staff were excellent. Highly recommended and will return.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: We stayed at a hotel nearby and the staff there recommended this restaurant. It was amazing!  You get an Argentine feel as soon as you enter... delicious food smells in the air, lots of wood decor, great ambiance.  Our Portuguese speaking server did not speak English however the menus had an English translation and with some pointing and hand waving we managed to order.  To say that the food was great would be a big understatement. Our steaks were the best that we had ever eaten! We are still talking about them and wondering if we'll ever have the chance to eat any that taste that good again. They were grilled and seasoned to perfection... not to mention VERY generous portions. The side dishes were plentiful and delicious as well.  And at the end of the meal, we were surprised by the bill... at how small it was! There were four of us dining and we had four steaks, four side dishes, a bottle of wine, a large bottle of beer and several bottles of water - our bill worked out to about $20 US each! Unbelievable for such a delicious and plentiful meal.  Needless to say we highly recommend this restaurant for an authentic Argentine experience and the best steaks you'll ever eat. If we return to Buenos Aires again, we will definitely dine here again!

I ate here two years ago. It was good enough to try again, particularly after reading recent reviews. I was particularly taken with chazcat99’s review of Jan 20 where he said his wife’s salmon and shrimp ravioli was the ravioli they ever tasted. I love ravioli but have rarely had a memorable one. Particularly in a steakhouse. So I ordered it. This was by far the best ravioli of my life. I am sorry i have no photos. They were round, plump (they are rarely plump enough) with a delicious fresh tasting shrimp and salmon filling in an ok white sauce.,But best of all for me there were no doughy edges. Oh, i wish i had a photo-the whole pasta was stuffed. I’m going back again soon for more. Hubby had a good chorizo steak and grilled veggies. The veggies were onions, green peppers, tomatoes, zucchini all in big pieces, I had a glass of malbec. I find malbec kinda dull, you had one, you’ve had them all, but this was better than most.,

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: We arrived at noon on Sunday and were the first ones there. Not for long, the restaurant filled up by 1 PM.  The service was prompt and professional. The food excellent. We ended our week in buenos Aires on a high note, and with minimum meat. My wife had the salmon and shrimp ravioli in Genovese sauce, a delicate white sauce. It may be the best ravioli we ever had. I ordered the lasagna boleonaise and it too was excellent. Portion sizes were generous and the price was moderate.
I recommend as a bruschetta eggplant starter, main course chorizo steak and dessert tiramisu. And to drink you can not miss the red wine Lugui Bosca.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: I guess I don't really have to write a review, just say we went to eat there 7 out of 9 nights! It is brilliant. Lovely staff, lovely setting, wonderful food. Loved it!

review_title: A pretty much flawless steak night out!
review: So yes you can wait for a bit to get into this restaurant but we were told half and hour and headed to a local bar for a beer. They were good to their word and on our return went pretty much straight in.  Excellent food... crisp salads, juicy ribeye steaks and friendly, attentive waiters. No complaints from us.

We fell upon this traditional parilla by accident as it was close to our hotel. We ate there twice during our trip to BA, Patagonia and Iguazú. My husband and me felt both meals were the best dinners we had during our holiday. The steaks were cooked to perfection and very reasonably priced, as were the wines. Our waiter was Osvaldo and he was a very helpful and attentive waiter. At the end of the meal we were given a free glass of champagne with our dessert, a nice touch. We would have no hesitation in recommending this restaurant. Depending on the day and time people want to eat it may be advisable to reserve a table.
We had not booked a table, but they find a place for us upstairs. Good service! The food was excellent! For the first time I didn’t finnish my steak - it was too big! :-)

user_tags: Foodie;60+ Traveler;Peace and Quiet Seeker;Beach Goer
review: Friends had recommended this restaurant and we are pleased we dined here. We just had to try an Argentinian T-bone steak and we weren't disappointed. It was delicious. Service from Franco was wonderful and the wine was superb. Highly recommend

Arrived on the weekend without a reservation, and were lucky to get a seat upstairs. A lovely bread basket arrived with a trio of treats including garlic (no idea how it was prepared, but unbelievable), tapenade, and a veggie type spread. They were all so delicious. We ordered the Gnocchi and the Lasagna, as wanted something a little lighter than a meat entrée. The portions were ample, and we enjoyed a lovely bottle of Malbec with our meal. Service was very good and we would recommend this restaurant.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Urban Explorer;History Buff;Thrill Seeker
review: Don Julio seems to be the tourist restaurant of choice these days but just a few blocks away is Camden del SoHo and an entirely satisfying dining experience. The fun starts with a waiter who enunciates his Spanish so carefully and predicts your responses so well, you’ll feel like a native. The food is great and the portions are ridiculously large (sharing one entree is a good option). Be Sure and order the grilled provolone salad; it’s not what you expect and is delicious. The ONLY downside was the Argentinian definitions of Medium and Well. Consider pointing to a picture on your phone of how you want your Steak since bloody and cold in the center is the local version of Medium.

We came here on the recommendation of our hotel which was only a block and a half away. We had really excellent steak here - we both had the bife de chorizo and the meat was among the nicest I have ever had at reasonable prices given the quality. The salad and fries and Malbec were very good too.  I would recommend booking this place and highly recommend the meat. There are plenty of other dishes beyond the steak including other meats and pasta too. It deserves the positive reviews it gets. Service was friendly with some English spoken and it’s a nice traditional style parrilla restaurant.  The locals on either side of us shared steaks rather than take one of their own. The bife de chorizo steaks are big enough for two to share. Apart from cutting the cost down it also leaves room for starters and/or desserts - that’s an option worth considering.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: Hotel we stayed in Buenos Aires recommended Calden for dinner.  Traditional Argentinian restaurant with all the expected traditionals, Parilla/ other meats, fish and home made pasta. We had steak and home made spinach ravioli with a salad.  Found the produce really good quality and all around a very enjoyable meal. Very generous portions. Had a glass of house red wine which was huge and very nice.  Staff was very friendly. Would def recommend

So nice to have a quality steak and meal in Buenos Aires. We endured a crappy lunch of non-edible pizza at a sub par restaurant and paid almost 75% of Calden’s. The skirt steak & mushrooms with cream sauce and cashews & spinach salad & fries with garlic were AMAZING! Highly recommend in Palmero SOHO. Worth the experience.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: The owner of our B&B recommended this restaurant and we went 4 times so you could say we were not disappointed. All the waiters were helpful, friendly and courteous and well, what can you say about Argentine beef that has not already been said! We loved it all, the beef, the salad, the roasted veggies, the bread, the wine! When next in Palermo we will return to this great restaurant.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review_title: A beautiful place, great service and delicious food
review: We had Lunch at Calden del Soho and loved it. The interior is beautiful, the staff was very friendly and attentive. Provoleta was delicous and the steak and salad were perfect. The best place we had lunch this time being in Buenos Aires as all the other restaurants we went to felt touristy, overpriced and were lacking service. We would highly recommend Calden del Soho.

review_title: MY CHOICE FOR ONE OF THE BEST IN BUENOS AIRES
review: I am a steak lover and one of my reasons for the trip was to try the Argentine beef. First, the beef is equal to Morton's, Fleming's, Ruth's Cris etc. You just get twice as much for a little less money (at the NAME restaurants). Not being a late night eater I choose lunch. I tried Don Julio, Calden and on a lesser known note Clarkes. All the steaks were fantastic. Ribeye, Lomo, Entrana. Clarkes was cheaper, Calden more warm and welcoming (thanks to Christian) and a fantastic pour of Vino Tinto. We shared the stuffed mushrooms, my wife loved the ravioli and my steak was perfect! Calden is my repeat choice.

However, the chef was in a rush to leave so our mains came while we were still having starter! He then left the building! The canelloni was delicious also.  I had a lot of steak in BA. I am only giving it 3 stars because the chef rushed. My steak was ordered medium rare and came out medium to well done. Not much blood at all. In fact the waiter was annoyed with the chef. I didn't enjoy it cooked as much as it was otherwise it would have been perfect. It couldn't go back as the chef was gone!
I came to Calden with me wife and we had some amazing mushrooms as starter and tenderloin steak! And the wine was just fantastic! Really recommend it!

user_tags: Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review: Visit with a few friends on business trip. The filet steak was truly delightful. Nice atmosphere very chilled out. Staff very attentive. Well worth a visit.

Ok, so, I don't even know what to write except that this was so far in my life the absolute best culinary experience so far. We went without a reservation and were super lucky that another couple cancelled short notice and we were able to be a part of the experience, and it was an experience. The food was amazing, the wine was high quality and paired perfectly to the food. Nicolas was a fantastic host. I can't fault a single aspect of the entire evening. I can only recommend that everyone that has the chance to experience this, should do it. Definitely reserve before you go because they are very popular but if you don't go you are missing out on an absolutely amazing experience. If I could I would go here once a week minimum. Bravo Nicolas and your team. Thank you for everything and we will see you next time we are in buenos aires!

review_title: Family or 'group' type of dining experience
review: First off warning about inability to find taxis on New Years Eve....UBER transportation suggested by hotel as taxi wait over 90minutes. UBER prices 6-7times higher rates than usual  Arrived on time at 930pm and greeted at bottom of staircase by server who spoke no English but gracious.  Upstairs we ascended to first floor and met other families and guests. Served bubbly wine and hung around WAITING for dinner for an hour. Tasty single appetizer offered for the hour.  1030pm Ascended another flight of stairs to warm/hot small room with basic tables and recorded music.  Served set menu (I believe they do offer vegetarian options) from Nicos' favourite winery I suspect. Not mine unfortunately.  Food was good as were wines - however AS FOODIE and lover of great wines would not have chosen this again as place to spend New Year's Eve. We were asked to use the same wine glasses from one tasting to the next - tacky. Home style cooking and presentation. Some dishes above average in taste - presentation average.  Desserts arrived as the clock struck 12 and we left shortly after.  While I would recommend this as REASONABLY priced wine/dine experience - and the food was good - I DON'T feel this listing deserves to rated number one dining location on TripAdvisor for BA.

This restaurant which is on the lobby level of the Sheraton Hotel is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. The quality of the food was mediocre for dinner and the service was slow. There is a half decent selection of wines. Breakfast was marginally better with a fairly good spread for the buffet but relatively pricey.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review: This is not only a great dinner but a great experience. We were all Americans with one local Argentine but the conversation flowed as freely as the wine. Great to meet with and share life stories with other expats in Buenos Aires. Lots of interesting people. As for the meal, we started with a welcoming cocktail : Vodka, Hesperedina, Jengibre, Aji Amarillo, Jugos de Naranja y Durazno. The six course meal included Pan Integral Casero (a roasted eggplant dish), Berenjena Asada, caldo de Guanciale con Cinco Porotos (an excellent soup), Risoto Negro de Sepia, Adobo de Chancho (the star of the show in my view — a roasted pork dish that was best pork I have had), and finishing with Cheesecake de Especias (a homemade cheesecake with a tangerine topping(delicious). Each course was terrific and accompanying by well matched wines. The star in wine for me was the Desquiciado Garnacha 2021. Thank you so much everyone for a magical evening.

This is always more of an event than a place per se. This is my third trip to Buenos Aires and third time visiting this special secret dining room in 16 years. The food is always exceptional and creatively prepared using fresh regional ingredients. Each of 5 courses is described in detail and paired with thoughtfully chosen wines. The chef is incredibly knowledgeable of wines and the stories behind them. His background in some of the best restaurants in New York City offers an interesting perspective. If the food and beverage were not enough, the interactions and friendships made with the guests takes the experience over the top. Everything about the timing and the interactions and the flow of the evening has always seemed to be “just the right amount of everything“. Bravo! (Get there soon as the chef is technically retired but still doing these special events on occasion.)

review_title: Great meal in a private home in Buenos Aires
review: My husband and I had an interesting evening with delicious food and great company at Casa Saltshaker. We enjoyed speaking to other international travellers and the food and matching wines were superb. Dan, our host and the chef explained all the dishes and spoke about living in Argentina. It was just prior to the elections and it was interesting to hear Dan's views! Highly recommended if you are visiting Buenos Aires.

It has been 10 years since my last visit to Buenos Aires and Casa Saltshaker was on my must do list. It was just as much an incredible experience as I remembered in my previous three visits. Each time I have been I have really enjoyed visiting with other guests from around the world. Even though I am not the most social person, I have felt very comfortable with this experience. Dan and Henry make everyone feel at home. The food is superb and the wine pairings are excellent. In addition it is a great place to share your current travel experiences and obtain excellent advice and recommendations.

review_title: Start of our Argentina experience in BUenos Aires
review: We had a fantastic evening at Casa Saltshaker on 9th Mar to kick off our holiday. It was great sitting with other nationalities enjoying good food, excellent wines and everyone sharing their travel plans and experiences. The food was great and we had a memorable experience. Thanks to Dan & Henry for everything. Roddy & Phyllis.
good food, good company, nice ambiance. Very enjoyable. Could have been nicer if there would have been more time, but we were rushed out (in a nice way). Should renovate tthe bathroom.

review_title: Overall, a good experience, but expected better food and wines
review: This is a “closed door restaurant” for a maximum of 10 diners served on a communal table. The food was as described on the SaltShaker site- decent home cooking. But other than the soup, none of the dishes were that great. The accompanying wines weren’t anything special either - just common, everyday wines in quality. The experience was more about being in somebody’s home and sharing conversation with a small group of people from around the world. At the price $80/pp plus tip, we found much better value elsewhere in Buenos Aires.

review_title: A highlight of our time in Buenos Aires
review: The evening we spent at Casa Salt Shaker was one of the best experiences we've had in Buenos Aires, and indeed one of the most interesting we've had throughout all of our travels anywhere. The "puerta cerrada" (or "closed door") movement is new to us, but we'll be searching it out more often. What sets Casa Salt Shaker apart (aside from the food and drink, but more on that later) is the communal table. While many closed door restaurants have gone to traditional restaurant style seating, Casa Salt Shaker has maintained their communal table which made for a delightful evening. We sat with 8 other English speaking guests from the US (living in Chile, and living in Alaska), UK and New Zealand. What a diverse and well traveled and engaging group!  Now - the food! Dan is a master in the kitchen! Three of us were pescatarians, so Dan made an entire pescatarian-friendly meal. The meat eaters among us were thrilled to take a break from their Argentine meat frenzy. We savored homemade bread, Peruvian ceviche, Timbuche (the most delicious cilantro/albacore soup I've ever had!), corn ravioli, pollack with chimichurri hollandaise, and pineapple cheesecake, along with perfectly paired wines. Along with being an extraordinary cook, Dan is also a wonderful conversationalist and we learned a lot about life as an expat in Argentina. Dan doesn't speak much English but is delightful with his shy smile and quiet demeanor. The $80 (US) that we spent each was an incredible value given the quality (and quantity) of the food and wine, No tiny tastes or mere splashes of wine here.

review_title: Truly the highlight of our trip to Buenos Aires
review: We had a fantastic time from the moment we arrived. The description of what to expect was precisely accurate. We really enjoyed meeting the other guests but the food was the star of the show. Every dish was attractively presented and absolutely delicious. The portions were perfect if not slightly large but everything was seasoned to perfection. The chef Dan brings vast food knowledge from years of experience, research, and from being a food writer. This is such a special experience that I strongly suggest you book it in advance as to not be disappointed if trying to do so after you arrive in Buenos Aires. When available, Dan also provides food-oriented day tours. We were lucky to spend a full day with him and it enriched our experience immensely as he has lived there for almost 20 years. His Spanish and English are perfect and he speaks several other languages.

Wow last night was worth recording now, not waiting till we are home. This was no ordinary experience as this was in a private home with a maximum of 10 guests from anywhere in the world. It turned out that there were only 4 of us last night and all English speaking so it was great. Dan and Henry made us very welcome in their home with a lovely cocktail to start. I could go on but i want to talk about the food. Dan serves 5 courses all paired with different wines. The food was amazing, i don't eat raw fish but last night i could have licked my plate and asked for more. Absolutely delicious. As was the Brussel sprout bisque, again something else i wouldn't eat at home. Griddled white asparagus next with amazing homemade XO sauce. Onto main of Ribeye beef with Peruvian yellow chili sauce and finished off with pear and burnt butter brownie. This meal was truly amazing, everthing beautifully presented,portions are not tiny, glad of the walk back to our apartment. Thanks Dan and Henry for a great night.

Dan Perlman presents cuisine that is interesting and pairs it with local wines. We had a great evening with a very diverse group of travelers which made for a lovely meal. i was relieved to not eat a "slab of beef". The food was very inventive and a mix of South American Cuisines. Don't miss the closed door dining experience in BA- if they are full, ask for another recommendation. I had the worst time contacting them on a mobile device so think ahead before you leave the country to make your reservation. Keep in mind they are restricted on seating to 10 or so and they don't serve 7 nights per week.

user_tags: Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review: Good food, amazing wine pairings, lovely hosts, and a nice cultural exchange. Casa SaltShaker is the most fun food experience I've had so far in South America.  A communal table is a great idea, plain and simple. You might have to be slightly outgoing to go here, but if you can bare the thought of meeting new, interesting people, and talking to them over food and wine, this is the place for you. I went to this in-house restaurant with a friend of mine, and we had a blast meeting people from the U.S., Germany, England and Argentina.  But over to the most important thing: the food and drinks. The night opened with an amazing yerba mate gin cocktail, accompanied by light conversation with our newly acquainted co-guests. Good whole wheat bread was quickly followed by a really good smoked mozzarella cheese starter. Like the rest of the meal, the dish was perfectly seasoned - and slightly spicy.  One of the two shining highlights of the night was the hummus and cauliflower soup, paired with an amazing chardonnay. A slight touch of chili gave the table a slight scare, but every spoonful made the soup increasingly more satisfying. This is the kind of soup I would like to keep 20 liters of in my freezer for comfort food emergencies.  The third dish of the night was the weirdest one. Burnt pasta with squid, tomatoes and eggplants. Some of the guests struggled with the texture of the pasta, but I didn't really mind. The flavors were exceptional, and the rosé wine pairing was surprisingly great.  The fourth course, the main course, was the star of the night for me. I hate when people overcook birds, but this night the stuffed quail was cooked perfectly pink. An amazing tahini sauce, the pancetta in the stuffing, the crunchy pomegranate seeds - everything came together to make a complete dish. A deep, rich cabernet sauvignon exemplified how wine heightens food.  For dessert, we got a juicy banana cake, paired with a rich chocolate mousse, peanut cream and a syrup with a chili sting. The paired dessert wine was not over-the-top sweet, and went well with the rich dessert.  I left the place stuffed, satisfied and happy. I would recommend Casa SaltShaker to anyone with an adventurous palate and an open mind. For the gourmets of the world: spend a night in this cozy house if you're in Buenos Aires.

Dan and Henri are extremely professional in attendance. Our dinner lasted about three hours, started on time and the food was delicious and different. The house fulfills exactly what is proposed: bringing people together at a table to talk about different subjects and prepared and served dishes masterfully combined with the most different and sparkling wines. I am Brazilian and share the table with a young American and Hong Kong, which was a beautiful memory and unforgettable experience. Well worth it and the proposition is true. Congratulations Dan and Henri besides thank you.

Love underground dining experience or "closed door" how it's called in other countries.  Excellent choice on dining companions - and everyone was very engaged in a conversation. Felt as a part of a salon.  Dan, the owner and the chef, took a great effort to prepare the meals. And trust me the kitchen he has to work in - is tiny! So I am sure it was a challenge.  I enjoyed the wine, the meal and the discussion.

user_tags: Foodie;Like a Local;Nature Lover;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review_title: Shockingly impersonal hosts. Decent food, nothing really outstanding! Mediocre Wines.
review: We had an OK night at casa SaltShaker, but in the end it was a disappointmet, because we  expected MUCH more.  First of all, the food was ok - there's nothing to complain about. However, it wasn't anyting really special. This is definitely NOT world class, in a city famous for its abundance of world class restaurants. Of course, this insight was a disappointment!  The best way to describe what I mean is:  If I was invited to a hobby cook's house and he cooked such a meal, it would be great. If however somebody pretending to be a knowledgable chef invited me to his and cooked this menu for me, I would clearly think that he was not trying nearly as hard as he could, but was saving efforts...  The Casa Saltshaker guys are definitely to be attributed to the hobby cook area...the problem is that TA rates them in the other category (and they think that they belong there...)  The HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT was however was the complete abscence of any personal interaction on behalf of the "hosts". When you "invite" somebody into your home and you do not wish to exchange even a word with your "guests", this is really a bummer. I had the feeling that they were desperate to put us through the process as quickly as possible, collect our money and send us home.  I certainly didn't feel welcome there.  Exemplatory for the attitude towards their guest was this episode:  Coming in I was thirsty and aksed for a glass of water. They rejected it by saying that they would start serving dinner in 10min. REALLY!? Is THAT hospitality?! No one had ever before denied me a glass of water :-)  Making up for the desaster that our hosts were was a quite nice mix of guests with whom we've had a fun evening anyway, despite the hosts (unfortunately not because of them :-)  Last but not least, the wine "pairing" we had with the meal was mediocre. We have had wine pairings in good places in Buenos Aires, so we know what can be expected in this price range. The guys either don't have a clue about wine or they simply don't care (I suppose it's the latter, because it fits the overall picture).

We booked this restaurant to celebrate my partners 40th birthday and I will certainly remember this meal for a long time. The food is local and fresh, but this means that menu is constantly changing. It is quite possible that you may not be a fan of a specific course, but the overall pairing of wine and food is excellent. They accept up to 10 people per evening, so you get a nice social experience that is completely different experience from going out to a restaurant. We had six of us that night and ended up going out afterwards with a couple of people that we met that night.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed our experience at Casa Saltshaker during our September trip to Buenos Aires. This was our first experienced of a closed door dinner and it was very positive. The setting was intimate, with the 10 of us situated around a common table. The group dynamic was fun and it was a great chance to exchange travel advise and compare out notes on Argentine culture. As virtually all the other reviews here attest, the food was excellent. Dan and Henry do an excellent job of presenting creative dishes with well paired wines. We will definitely be trying some of his recipes. Dan is an especially hospitable host and gave great advise about the dining scene in Buenos Aires.

user_tags: Foodie;Like a Local;60+ Traveler;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review: Appetizers with a welcoming glass of wine on the upper terrace was the beginning of a wonderful dinner/wine pairing experience. Santiago is a charming host who immediately puts his guests at ease by explaining there are no correct pairings with food. Wine is very personal and the correct pairing is one that you enjoy. We had excellent dishes that were served with a variety of wines. For example, we were asked to taste and choose from three different vintages of Malbecs before we ate and again while we were eating. We found that our favorite changed when paired with our meal. Santiago, as a sommelier, gave us excellent background information on Argentinian wine regions and specifics of the wines served. The pairings included a variety of whites, reds and a “dessert” wine. It was an enjoyable evening with easy conversation with another nice couple and Santiago.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Thrill Seeker;Nature Lover
review: What a fantastic way to experience the tastes of Argentina! It's like having dinner at your Argentinian friends' house that you didn't know you had. The hosts were so friendly and knowledgeable, especially about the wine. We tried seven different wines, and I don't mean a small taste. They really encouraged us to try different wines with different foods. The food was excellent, as was the wine. Sure it's not the typical restaurant experience, but get outside your comfort zone. It's well worth it. We enjoyed meeting the other guests, and the Owners took such great care of us. This was one of our favorite dining experiences in all of Argentina!

user_tags: Foodie;Urban Explorer;Shopping Fanatic;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review: This restaurant has been reserved for our last night in BA and we have been very satisfied. The food, from starter to dessert, managed to surprise us with new tastes. The tataki salmon was probably the highlight, together with the crispy peas: delicious and cooked to perfection. It was great to have suggestions on the wine paring, and to be able to taste different wine types. The sweet Malbec was another discovery, we took a bottle home. The prices are fair and the service very attentive. We spent a nice evening at Casa Coupage!

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Nightlife Seeker
review_title: Personal, warm, tasty food, excellent wine, great night overall
review: We were lucky to visit our friends in this lovely city and have been introduced to Casa Coupage at our first night out. The food, the service and the attention to detail was amazing. We have tried the tasting menu and the wine pairing is spot on. I am not a big fun of Malbec, and I was presented with a variety of great dry whites and an amazing pinot blanc Rose that tasts nothing like a rose wine called Lagarde. Highly recommended.  The food is top quality and a personal experience. They make you feel like you are dining at your friend's house. One of the most memorable evenings for a long time.

Lovely, quirky and small restaurant. They serve a tasting menu with very reasonably priced wines to accompany it, or you can go a la carte and either choose a bottle or, again, ask them to recommend wines by the glass. In the wine list they will do 3, 5 or 7 glasses for a set price, so you know what you will be paying. The whole meal was very good value. I wasn't keen on one of the wines and Salvatore changed it immediately, without any hesitation.  The food was very good, but, as others have commented, the wine is really the star. A pleasant experience, although it is very intimate so difficult not to overhear others' conversations whilst you are dining.  The hosts are charming, a really friendly couple and both speak excellent English.  A word of warning about finding it: the street it is located on is very long, we nearly made the mistake of walking from our hotel in Palermo Soho, and it doesn't feel like a very safe neighbourhood. Our taxi driver mistook the address so had to drop us two blocks further down the road as it's a one-way street, and we didn't feel very comfortable walking, especially as we managed to miss it altogether at first. Make sure your taxi driver gets the house number right.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: Delightful beautifully served multi-course dinner but the wine pairing is a must. Co-owner Santiago treats you to the joy of argentine wines. Well worth a visit to those interested

review_title: Amazing tasting menu with wine pairings in the perfect setting!
review: Just enjoyed dinner at Casa Coupage last night. The tasting menu and wine pairings were fantastic. Dinner was served by a lovely waitress and all of our pairings were put together by Santiago, one of the owners and a sommelier. The "closed door" restaurant was in an unmarked house in Palermo, very charming. We selected the tasting menu ($350 pesos per person) and did 5 wine pairings. At the end we ended up receiving a total of 7 wines including a sparkling wine upon arrival and an extra white from Santiago. The pours were huge and I would highly reconmend doing the pairing (an extra $170 pesos) Dinner was wonderful but be warned we were there for 4.5 hours! You almost needed that much time to drink as much wine as we did! We also got totally wrapped up in a game of "guess the essence from the sommelier kit" with Santiago. Even still I wouldn't plan on leaving in much under 4 hours. We were there with friends so it was a great time and the food was fantastic. A very special dinner in BA.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: An old colonial era style house converted to a comfortable old style restaurant - elegant and calming. Is of the "closed door" variety so popular in BA so a reservation is required...  Food was lovely - small tasting dishes in a multi-course menu are probably the most interesting option. No huge hunks of meat here - dishes are all fairly delicate and of excellent size so you come away feeling satisfied but not stuffed.. The best bit is the wine pairings.. The owners are someliers/wine enthusiasts and offer a wine paring option with the menus where you can taste (copious, generous quantities) wines with each course; often 2 per course so that comparisons can be made... It's a really good intro to Argentinian wines for several different regions and grape varieties. And the price??? -- per head around U$D100....  Go. You won't be disappointed.

This was the second closed-door restaurant we tried and it was completely different than our first. Much more like a typical restaurant in that we had our own table and there was staff serving. Incredible 7 course tasting menu paired with 5 wines. This was by far my favorite restaurant. Not cheap, but excellent! Splurge on this! You won't regret it!

Wow, expensive yes, but you will never forget this three hour tasting pleasure. We chose three wine pairings to our seven courses and not only were the presented beautifully they tasted even better. Have never dined in a closed door restaraunt, but wish they would allow this in the states. Go dot not hesitate, as it is truly something "to write home about". Reservations in advance are a must, don't miss this rare gem.....

The best meal I had in Buenos Aires. It is worth every penny. The staff is super nice and insightful on the food. My water was never empty once. The creativity here is 10/10. For the dessert course, we were moved to the 2nd floor in a private room since we had a group of 5. Very nice touches in the room. There were some dishes I liked more than others but I would definitely come here every time I am in Buenos Aires. Must make reservations in advance but definitely worth the wait.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;History Buff
review: I saw a trip advisor email about this restaurant. Very intimate. Only about 10 tables. It has an open kitchen so you can watch your meals being made. Our dinner was a 17-course tasting meal. They are able to accommodate dietary preferences & requirements.

I was served the multi-course tasting menu with wine pairings while seated at the chef's table. I received excellent service throughout, in English, with multiple staff serving, and a dedicated sommelier attending to both me and other guests.  I really enjoyed the atmosphere and the whole experience. For a visitor from the UK, this meal represented excellent value for money and so was an opportunity I could not pass up.  Photographs are provided for reference only, the restaurant seeks to surprise guests so I decline to state exactly what is in each course.  The staff will try to cater for allergies.

review_title: Spectacular meal with just a tiny bit of room for improvement
review: This is one of those fancy restaurants that serve you a multiple course tasting menu. I have to admit that I’ve been to a few of these. I enjoy the opportunity to taste lots of different things and the surprise of what might come next. So when I was in Buenos Aires, I decided to try Aramburu.  A lovely ambience in the restaurant, and as expected of a fancy restaurant, the level of the service from the staff was superb. Ever attentive, always friendly. I was lucky to be sat at one of the chef’s table, facing the kitchen, and was able to witness the magnificent way the whole process seem to run so smoothly.  All that counts for nothing though if the food is not right, so what did I think? It didn’t start well. The starter course on the whole was a flop for me. They look amazing, but the taste just did not match. Take the soup & potato crisp that we started with. Both parts were way too salty. The next 2 plates of 3 bite-size food was underwhelming, and I really didn’t understand that carrot tartare. Why? From that first part, the only thing I really enjoyed was the baby goat in donut pastry.  Fortunately, things kicked up a notch after that. In sporting terms, the next 6 courses were absolute home runs. Oyster in coconut milk & granita, mushroom with egg yolk, shrimp & endive salad, fish with Jerusalem artichoke, quail, deer. Ah, heavens. I’m really not a salad person, so it comes as a surprise to myself that the shrimp & endive salad was one of the tastiest thing I’ve ever had. The combination of flavours and textures was just mind-blowing. The mushroom dish had such intense flavour. The quail was cooked to perfection. I could go on, but I’m making myself hungry. Suffice to say they lived up to the best dishes that I’ve had anywhere in the world.  After the amazing highs of the section I consider mains, the desserts were a bit of a come down. Don’t get me wrong they were not bad. The palate cleanser was smart & interesting, and both the pre-dessert and the main dessert were tasty, but they were just not spectacularly amazing, which was the standard that was set by the mains.  Given the quality of the food and service, the cost of the evening was really quite reasonable.  Overall, if there were some changes made to the starter section, this could very well best meal that I have ever had. I was very close to overlooking my dislike of the starters and giving it 5 stars, but I think it’s fairer to give it 4. If I’m back in Buenos Aires, I would go again, and cross my fingers that I can give it a full 5 stars next time.

What more can I say besides WOW!! What an amazing experience. I found Aramburu online and decided to visit from Australia. I can honestly say this place is worth the effort to travel to just to experience the amazing food and top service. We chose the tasting menu paired with wine. Each and every course along with cleansers and tasters were fantastic. The wait staff really made the experience special knowing the menu so well and being able to speak perfect English (helped my average Spanish :) ) The Sommelier truely made the experience. Her understanding and conveying of the wine was second to none. Even when asked for additional information and wine she was more than helpful. This place was so worth the trip from Perth to try. Do yourself a favour and treat yourself to a wonderful meal and experience by trying Aramburu. It was fantastic...

Every dish was delicious. Service was excellent and the wine served with the tasting menu was superb. Can't believe the very reasonable price. When you arrive by taxi, it looks like you're at an abandoned store. Ring the doorbell, and you'll be admitted by the smiling hostess. This was truly one of our finest dining experiences in South America. If I lived in B.A., I would dine here whenever the menu changed.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: We treated ourselves to a 16 course meal with matching Argentine wine during our short stay in BA. What a wonderful experience; excellent and beautiful food, great service and lovely wine. The sommelier was excellent as was the waitresses. Highlight courses were the appetisers especially the scallop ball, the prawn and fish soup, beef and ice cream sandwich. Such great value so book early!

An echo of other reviews ... getting in to the restaurant is similar to a speakeasy (it looks like a boarded up shop) but the atmosphere inside is excellent. The 18 courses were fantastic, my only complaint is that there is just too much food (I'd ditch a couple of courses ...the bread and one of the shellfish courses). The wine pairings were really great, staff friendly and knowlegable ... An excellent meal, save room for the popcorn ice cream.

Really love this restaurant! Providing an 18 course tasting menu (with an optional wine pairing selection) this small venue (less an 20 tables) provides an intimate evening serving seasonal and delicious local food.  Service is friendly and attentive. All dishes are clearly explained and are uniquely presented. A great place for a ‘highlight’ meal. Try to enjoy this place before it moves to the more upmarket Recoleta area in March 2019.  Dinner takes about 2 hours. Sit back, relax and enjoy a wonderful taste experience.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: It was top on TA and also on the top 50places in Latin America.  The outside is so inconspicuous that you would walk pass it.  Nice interior with focus lighting on tables.  Good service.  1option: 18 courses with or with paired wines: took the paid wine option.  Cost:3900pesos  Food: the first serving is selection of crackers: all amazing followed with 6 bite sizes dishes. This included pumpkin log, scallops , pea in a pod, avocado on kale, duck pate with strawberry: all amazing.  Next it was bread with smoked butter- wasn’t particularly wowed by it.  Next came the bigger dishes: Beetroot with squid: interesting,squid was extremely soft. Scrimp on a hot stone : nice, interesting almost Tom yum like soup Fish with crispy skin : very good Chinese dumplings of goat with citrus : excellent Quail fried: excellent Beef: which was ok  3 deserts include: Grapefruit skin with jelly of Sauvignon Blanc and citrus: excellent Popcorn like desert : superb Lastly: a desert of meringue, coconut scrapings : again excellent.  Value for money: although pricey it is great value for money if you come from the UK,Europe or US where this meal would have cost double or triple .  It is one of the best meals of my life and can rival Michelin stars in Europe!

user_tags: Foodie;Shopping Fanatic;Peace and Quiet Seeker;Beach Goer
review_title: Almost 4 hrs of delight for your eyes and taste buds!
review: Blown away is an understatement. We were lucky enough to discover this place because our AirBnB was two doors down (literally!). You come across the front door, which looks like an abandoned storefront, ring the doorbell, then enter into the most intimate, romantic, charming place ever. You are blown away from the very first course. A truly artistic vision. And DELICIOUS! Each course is amazingly paired with wine. We ate and drank for 3.5 hours (a record for me!) but did not leave drunk or stuffed. Full and giddy would be a more accurate description. I truly hope you have a chance to visit this wonderful secret. And the price is surprisingly affordable (in American terms - we paid just over $100 per person).

The last time I had eaten in Aramburu, I ate alone. This time, it was with my wife. We opted for the 20 course menu, paired with 6 wines. The bill came to about US$ 90 per head. The staff asked as we sat down if we had any food no-nos and, once explained, all the courses were adjusted accordingly with no fuss. Needless to say, each course was imaginatively presented and contained an unusual mixture of sumptuous flavours. Each time our wine glasses were empty, they were refilled without our needing to ask. We at at Baqueano's the following evening and neither of the aforementioned was the case. The wines were superb, especially the Susana Balbo White Blend. We can't wait for our next trip to Buenos Aires to visit again.

I am giving this 4 stars because of the wonderful service. However in my experience the food was disappointing. This trip I am trying to eat a bit healthier ordering vegetable plates along with steak. The vegetables were overcooked and visually unappealing. The salad I ordered was drenched with way too much salad dressing. When I arrived the restaurant was empty but when leaving it was full.

user_tags: Urban Explorer;Like a Local;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review: We enjoyed the food, service & atmosphere all very good and it was busy and popular with locals later in the evening we had pasta dishes as we wanted a change but the meat dishes also looked good. Great salad starter with apple ,Parm hearts & cheese delicious!!

This will be my first stop the next time I visit Buenos Aires. Excellent high quality steak and very good service. A banquet at a very low price.  The restaurant was not packed but there were plenty of people, and still the service was excellent and my food arrived fast. They take credit cards. I recommend the bife de chorizo, salad, and espresso. Can be accompanied by wine or good beers.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: Traditional restaurant, with the usual choice of meats and pasta. Good food, friendly service although rather slow. Good option, nothing worth mentioning.

We went early (we were actually the first table for lunch on a week day). The host and the waiter were very friendly and the place, all in colourful wood, is truly nice. Upon arrival, we were given a bread basket with a special parsley mayo.  My mom (because I went with my mom) got a light salad and I went for the 'suprema al verdeo con papas noisette', which in English sounds like 'chicken schnitzel with green onions and noisette potatoes'. After that, we had the 'Copa Escocia' (Scotland Cup) that you will love.  My mom wanted to use a special voucher she had, and even if there was something missing (like a code I guess) they anyway gave us the discount, which we appreciated.  Thumbs up!

user_tags: Foodie;Like a Local;Peace and Quiet Seeker;Luxury Traveler
review: It is always good to be able to eat outside in between the trees. I had the Brotola and the fish accompanied with a nice glass of Sauvignon from Argentina was tasty.

We chose Las Canas after scrolling through Trip Advisor and reading some good reviews. The food is ok, nothing to fave about and there are much better options for steak in s similar area. The pasta was fine but again nothing to special. Staff are friendly and welcoming although our waiter didn't speak English he was very accomodating with us and our limited Spanish. It's nice for a quick cheap dinner however would say the nice service outweighs the quality of the food.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Urban Explorer;Like a Local;History Buff
review: Las Canas is on the edge of the theatre district in Buenos Aires. I found it on TripAdvisor and was not disappointed! They serve pasta, seafood and steak. On the advice of Diego I chose a pasta dish that was superb, assisted by a lovely Argentinean Malbec it made a very complete meal. Nice ambience, very reasonable prices and excellent service. Ask for Juan or Diego. Highly recommended, another top restaurant in Buenos Aires.

user_tags: Thrill Seeker;Peace and Quiet Seeker;Luxury Traveler
review: Very nice place and fancy with garden Service excellent and food wonderful including T bone and ravioli; Some how expensive

I booked this restaurant several months in advanced as it was my wife's birthday meal and we were only in BA for 3 nights. Reservation was cancelled a few weeks before as the restaurant said they were closed for a wedding party. After several emails with Clara the reservation was still possible. I mentioned it was my wife's birthday and was hoping for cake or something, but disappointed that I did not receive this especially as Clara had mentioned this in her emails to me.  However the food was good, the service and the staff not the friendliest I found but the garden was nice.

This spot was recommended to us by our hotel concierge and we were very pleased that he had done so.  Yamile was our server and she did a fantastic job.  Many in the group ordered steak. I had the ravioli dish which was very rich and satisfying. Six of us had a full dinner with beer and wine for only $115 US. Great value!
We found this place by chance and what a find. Only had mains but from the moment we entered we felt special.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Nature Lover;Luxury Traveler
review: We had a reservation for New Year’s Day. Unfortunately they were out of lamb, which was our first choice. The steak was very good as was the wine selection. However, there were several things that affected our experience. First, one of the hostesses kept spraying an awful air freshener. It reminded me of being on an airplane in certain countries when they disinfect the plane. Horrible! My husband later learned that they were using it to camouflage a sewage problem they were experiencing in the men’s room. Our waiter started out great, but we never saw him after placing our order as he was then moved to serve a large party. Consequently we never had service again. We had to wait 40 minutes to get our check. A hostess noticed my dissatisfaction when leaving and asked if everything was okay. When I explained about the service, she just said they were busy. I think there are better restaurants to spend your money in than Cabernet.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: Couldn't get into Don Julio but no problem because wwe found this place close by. And what a find. Amazing steaks and Malbec. Will happily go back when next in BA.

We had our first ever meal in South America at Cabernet based on the advice of our driver, and we were not disappointed. The chorizo appetiser was massive, but beautiful and very juicy - better even than Don Julio’s. The sirloin in red wine reduction was superb, and the waiters coped very well with our complete lack of Spanish, and request for a gluten free meal. The wine choice was spot on and the service generous, professional and warm. Seating options are inside, or a lovely covered adjoining courtyard facing a fabulous lovely street.

Located in the heart of Palermo. A balanced atmosphere between elegance, classic style and modernity. Fast and very discreet service. We tried various cuts and types of meat, always excellent and really well cooked. Excellent choice

review_title: Nice ambiance, good food, great service
review: We had dinner at Cabernet and enjoyed it!! The food is good nothing extraordinary but good. Loved the ambiance and decor. I would recommend this place for a special occasion or an intimate, romantic dinner. Service was exceptional!! Our waitress, Yamile, was outstanding, very attentive and very sweet. She made our night extra special. A real gem... Definitely recommend this place when in Palermo

review_title: Fantastic steak on our last night in Argentina!
review: Spotted this restaurant walking past at lunchtime and decided to return for dinner. I wanted an Argentinian steak! (For our last night in Argentina and also the last night of our 9 week round the world, once in a lifetime vacation! I was not disappointed, Jonatan recommended a lovely Cabernet Franc wine and looked after us supremely well. The sophisticated ambiance of this place is classic and relaxed. Ideal to dine in couples or groups. Don’t walk by this place or you’ll miss a great restaurant!
Found this jewel as we were walking around the city. Talk about atmosphere we sat outside had wine and lunch. Having eating steak all week I went for the pork special what a great meal.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Nature Lover
review: It was our first night in BA after a long long flight from Europe. We were wandering around in Palermo and when dinner time came, we looked around. We saw this place and it was very inviting. There’s a more formal dinner room with white tablecloths inside but as the temperatures were still mild we chose the inner leafy courtyard. Kevin had his first Patagonia beer and it became his favourite... We ordered also a bottle of Malbec from Cafayate. Smooth flavoursome. As we say in French “le petit jésus en culotte de velours”... And of course we had steaks. My husband’s thick entrecôte was grilled to perfection. A lovely crust and juicy inside. So tender. So tasty. I had a skirt streak. Amazing too. We undoubtedly understood the reputation of Argentinian beef! The best we ever had! It does put to shame the French Limousin and Charolais beef... We’ll surely come back there for our coming stay in Buenos Aires.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Vegetarian;Like a Local;History Buff
review: Great Atmosphere! Cuisine “well presented” WHY 3 STARS: 1)We ordered two appetizers and two entrees.. the volume of food was enormous, however neither of us appreciated the taste of anything provided... and we are not food snobs or foodies as some call themselves. 2)We were charged for the napkins and bread provided on the table that we never requested! We travel the world and this was a first for us globe trotters. 3)We were charged for wine that we did not drink... this was promptly removed when we disputed the bill.. *** Great atmosphere... However overall, I would not recommend this restaurant to a friend without serious warnings regarding the overall package. RNelson (Austin,TX)

review_title: Good food service a little slow
review: Ate here on a rainy night as such we couldn’t eat outside which would have been nice as there courtyard is lovely. The food and wine were both very nice however the service was very slow. We ordered and didn’t receive are drinks for some time. Would come back however as the food was very nice and staff pleasant.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Vegetarian;Foodie;Like a Local
review: We late lunched here outside in the courtyard after our morning tour of the city and a pretty long walk back from the Museum of Bellas Artes, with pretty high hopes based on TA reviews. I have to say that I was not blown away with either the food (I chose the spinach gnocchi) or the slightly disinterested service, so am not able to give it my recommendation.

review_title: A lovely last evening in Buenos Aires
review: This was recommended to us by our BA guide. He listed it as in Palermo but it is really in Soho and quite a trek from our Palermo hotel – so we took a cab. It was in a part of this enormous city that we had not visited so it was great to see such a ‘buzz’ going on. The restaurant was quiet at 7.30 but filled up as the evening progressed. The food was pretty good but not mind blowing but at a reasonable cost and the waitresses that served us were a delight and very helpful.

We came across this restaurant by chance looking for somewhere to eat on a rainy September evening. We enjoyed the setting in a lovely old house as well as the quiet atmosphere. The service was good though it helped being able to speak a little Spanish.  The wine list is very extensive.  We both had fish dishes which were nicely prepared. The prices are a bit on the high side for Buenos Aires.

review_title: Cool place to eat nice meat
review: If you want to eat meat this is the place!! Portions super generous too big for us but quality meat. Ice cream? No it is not an ice cream it was 4 ice creams! Service very kinds good English and jokes! Like it a lot! Restaurant cool too with characteristics lights and signed plated! Prices excellent too recommended!

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Peace and Quiet Seeker
review: I read that Cabrera is one of the best steakhouses of Buenos Aires so I had some expectations. Unfortunately they were not met.  Nice Restaurant in local design. Service is soso, not very attentive and not overly friendly.  Food is very disappointing, the salad was ok but the oil and vinegar they use is very low quality. The beef (I ordered a fillet) was not tender and the taste was not good. Also the side dishes were not good. Very disappointing as I know Argentinian beef can be fantastic.  I do not understand this restaurant is rated so high, for me a very average restaurant. I cannot recommend and will definitely not return.

user_tags: Nature Lover;Eco-tourist;Peace and Quiet Seeker;Beach Goer
review: We came here with a large group from the office and had a huge lunch, including sampling the appetizers and sharing salads. It’s mainly a place for eating huge amount of meat but on the other side the salads are very good and large as well. All the food was good and the service very friendly. Nice location in a very cool setting

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review_title: Good Food with a Quirky Touristy Ambiance
review: The food was good. If you’re into touristy ambiance, this is the place. The restaurant is decorated with eclectic items throughout. The food would’ve been better if the server didn’t insist on what we should order and how we should order. Having travelled in many places and eaten at many restaurants, I find it very annoying when server treats American as if we’ve never eaten foreign meals before. How foreign can steak really be!?!? I like the idea of the many different condiments and side items served with the meal on the first visit just to have the different tastes of flavors they offer but I wouldn’t care for it on my next visit. I would come here again but I would insist on ordering what I like rather than what the server insists. I would be more selective on the side items rather than many different items that I don’t care for. For dessert, I ordered a flan which was overwhelming even for 3 people. Flan is already very sweet but they served with large portion of dulce leche.

We popped in for lunch but even lunch was super busy so BE SURE to book! Service was very friendly and we sat in the terrace which was nicely decorated. Loved the bread basket and multiple sides which were complimentary, one was a salad which we usually order so that was great to see. We shared the 700g steak, it was well cooked and delicious. We also ordered papas frittes, which looked delicious but we were so pleased they didn't come. The wine list was great and we enjoyed a nice bottle of Malbec. After our meal we were so full so no dessert. La Cabrera Norte was one of our favorite restaurants in BA. Definitely check it out.

This had been recommended by several people and was our first restaurant visit in BA. There are 2 locations close to each other, so make sure if you make a reservation ( highly recommended) that you know which one you have booked. We were booked for Saturday 8.30 and it was packed. Great atmosphere and waiters were very entertaining (English spoken well). Excellent wine recommendation “Niento Senetiner” Malbec to go with our 2 steaks with massive portions of Patatas frites and mixed salad. Good value and great service and atmosphere - a winner

review_title: Excellent diner with my wife and daughter
review: We got recommendations from 2 sides and could make a reservations. We had a very friendly waiter who gave a very good advice on the type of meets to choose. All this together with a nice Malbec and we finished with the banane flambée.

review_title: Another good meat restaurant in BA
review: I went for the Cabreara Sur and was redirected to this branch only one block distant (it was holiday and the restaurant was full). Specialized in meat, the restaurant located at Palermo has high prices (but good cost-benefit relation because of its quality).Service only OK. The meat was very good.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review: Referred by friends. A bit distance from city center but well worth the taxi ride. Crowded, local, and excellent food. An excellent choice for a taste of Buenos Aires.

Had to wait a bit for a table, but was given a drink while we waited. Waiter was very good & entertaining. We shared 2 massive steaks & some salads between five of us and three bottles of wine and paid the equivalent to $45 NZ dollars. You cannot eat & drink that cheaply where I am from. Such an enjoyable evening & food was fantastic.

review_title: Steak ! Steak! Did I mention steak?
review: Thoroughly enjoyed this adorable restaurant. Family of four.  We ordered two steaks and two salads - typically we have a gigantic appetite for steak and it was a huge amount of food - we suggest you SHARE STEAK AND ONE SALAD MAX PER FOUR PEOPLE.  If you are used to American Caesar salad we suggest passing on this, as their version wasn't what we are used to. Take a look at the other salads as they pass by - very large and deconstructed style. They offer half portions.  The decor of this restaurant was great with drawn on plates by past customers covering the walls and small air planes and toy blimps along the ceilings. It was filled with tourists but we didn't find it "too touristy".  The wait staff were very lovely and kind, spoke English very well.  Our only criticism would be that the food seemed to be rushed - the salad, steaks, and sides all came rushing to the table all at once very quickly overwhelming the table.  Would suggest this to our friends in the future !

We had a great time with our friends there. Food was very good. The steaks came cooked as ordered and were great. Service was great, too. This restaurant is well known and always packed. You will need a reservation.

review_title: Mains Terrible but Service and Complimentary items Great
review: Overall I would say this restaurant didn't really live up to expectations, especially since it is very expensive.  We ordered two different chicken dishes, while we waited were served a plethora complimentary items, all very tasty and almost worth visiting for alone. Also the service was very good (something quiet uncommon in Argentina). We were a little put off by the paper table cloth and ikea style glasses, I think at this price they can do better.  Still we were really happy until the mains arrived, these we exceptionally dry, fatty and tasteless. If I had cooked that at home I would be apologising to my family. One dish was virtually inedible because it had been crisped so much on the outside and the inside was tasteless. Very disappointing.

A magnificent steak collection with info on how to order. Waiters dont always speak english. The steak was superb and well cooked. The condiments were out of this world as was the free salad. Desserts were massive
Superb meat and a very good choice. Nice cool atmosphere and good service. Nice wines and perfect for a fun evening

user_tags: Urban Explorer;Like a Local;History Buff;Thrill Seeker
review: Great food and service. The owner really takes care of his guests. I would add the provenance of the wine in the wine menu together with the year of production.

I went to a number of steakhouses during my trip, including Don Julio. Parrilla Voro Carnes is the best, in my view. I can twice and the ribeye is amazing. Owner Ilia personalizes the experience and I suggest to follow his recommendations. The wine by the glass was chosen well and is generously served. Highly recommend!!-

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;History Buff
review_title: Perfect steaks. Friendly and personal service
review: We found this restaurant on TA and decided to give it a try. Upon arrival, the owner greeted us personally and explained everything. It turned out that he immigrated many years ago from Ukraine/Russia who initially studied something else but finally fulfilled his dream and opened a restaurant in Buenos Aires. The service and attitude couldn’t have been friendlier and more natural. We both decided to habe beef (of course) with grilled vegetables and papas fritas with garlic. The food was served fast and smoothly and it was just perfect. Altogether a great, high quality but also unpretentious dining experience for a very reasonable price.

From the moment we walked into Voro, we knew it was going to be a great evening. The restaurant is owned by a lovely couple who are obviously striving to provide a wonderful ambience and top quality food for a reasonable price. Our steaks were delicious and cooked to perfection, as we’d requested. This is a lovely restaurant and I would highly recommend it.

Was looking for a nice spot for a beer after arriving in BA and down the street from the hotel a bit, we found Sullivan’s. Stopped in for a local beer and enjoyed the setting so much we decided to have dinner here. The menu is smallish but the food was good and reasonably priced. We had a bottle of Argentinian white wine form north of the country and it was very good.All in all a great spot if you live in the Palermo district.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Urban Explorer;Like a Local
review_title: Nice Irish Pub, AC, TVs... disappointing breakfast
review: I stopped in here looking for a traditional breakfast. There was a rugby game going on and the place was full with fans. I found a table and enjoy the air conditioning as it was a hot day out. After looking over the menu for a while I ordered what I thought was scrambled eggs with bacon and draft beer. What I got was ham and eggs other the ham had a bunch of chunks of bone in it. My draft beer was tiny and seemed kind of expensive. Nice spot to beat the heat, not sure I would seek this place out unless you wanted to watch a soccer or rugby game with local fans.
A nice place to sit down for a beer or two! We ordered Pantagonia Pilsener. The service and atmosphere was great!
We popped in for a beer and some wine to get out of the rain and nice atmosphere . Good happy hour deal and complimentary popcorn. Lovely staff so no complaints.

user_tags: Like a Local;History Buff;Thrill Seeker;Nature Lover
review: The closed-door restaurant was a foreign concept to us and sounded intriguing when I saw it on TripAdvisor. There were two other couples who joined us so it was interesting meeting new people. We were at the end of our two week trip in northern Patagonia so had tried nearly everything already somewhere else along our journey. But it was nice to have a great variety of offerings all at once between the charcuterie tray, meat appetizers, provoleta, main beef dish, and dessert. The dessert was something new and very tasty. Our provoleta was overcooked and drier than all the others we had eaten over our two weeks in region. The commentary Luis provided was professional and educational and it was nice to be able to go watch the cooking in action. I would recommend the experience to first-timers to BA.

user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;History Buff;Nature Lover
review: We have literally traveled all over the world in the last couple of years and have had some of the most wonderful dining experiences ever-but NONE of them compare to the wonderful evening we just had hosted by Luis! Asado-the Argentinian custom of sharing good food and barbecued meats- a tradition that we now love!
